code: @Manual{,   title = {Useful.functions: Some Useful Functions},   author = {Esther Herbert},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.3.0.9000},   url = {https://estherherbert.github.io/Useful.functions/}, }

title: Some Useful Functions
text: package brings together functions created perform repetitive tasks. NB: README file work progress, info functions please see specific help files package installed

title: Some Useful Functions
text: Install latest release following code: ’d like install latest development version can omit @*release call install_github().

title: Some Useful Functions
text: Functions package roughly split following categories: Working data Prospect Summary tables Functions use xtable::xtable() functions

title: Some Useful Functions
text: Addins functions used interactively within RStudio. three Addins provided package keyboard short cuts can created speed coding. information Addins can found, including set keyboard short cuts, . Insert Section End Box Month Year

title: Some Useful Functions
text: save time writing statistics reports created R Markdown template. Currently report exports pdf (personal preference) modified export word. can access template either creating new R Markdown document menu RStudio looking templates using rmarkdown::draft("-report.Rmd", template = "statistics-report", package = "Useful.functions"). options create folder report name containing markdown file templates required generate report. recommend render pdf using rmarkdown::render rather using knit button.

title: Some Useful Functions
text: Similar report template, R Markdown template creates pdf presentation using beamer document class LaTeX.

title: Some Useful Functions
text: project template sets recommended folder structure analysis. also copies template Master.R Read-data.R scripts. Optionally, can also: set-.gitignore file create project specific .Rprofile open Master.R whenever project opened. use report template start statistics report can access project template either using start_analysis() function, creating new project RStudio menu.

title: Useful.functions: Some Useful Functions — Useful.functions-package
text: package (one paragraph).

title: Useful.functions: Some Useful Functions — Useful.functions-package
text: Maintainer: Esther Herbert E.Herbert@sheffield.ac.uk

what: Adds LaTex \clines to an object of class
title: Adds LaTex \clines to an object of class
text: Produces list 'pos' 'command' use xtable()'s add..row option. create partial horizontal line across specified columns table. Users can either specify row numbers like add cline function look rows use multirow specified column.

title: Adds LaTex \clines to an object of class
Adds LaTex \clines to an object of class
text: xtab xtable object rows either "multirow" (default) row numbers add cline cols character string columns draw cline (e.g, "2-3") check.column character string column check rows = "multirow"

title: Adds LaTex \clines to an object of class
text: list levels 'pos' 'command' give add..row option xtable().

title: Adds LaTex \clines to an object of class
code: xtab <- xtable::xtable(head(iris))  xtable::print.xtable(xtab, add.to.row = add_clines(., rows = c(2, 3), cols = "3-4")) #> % latex table generated in R 4.5.1 by xtable 1.8-4 package #> % Fri Aug 29 09:52:47 2025 #> \begin{table}[ht] #> \centering #> \begin{tabular}{rrrrrl} #>   \hline #>  & Sepal.Length & Sepal.Width & Petal.Length & Petal.Width & Species \\  #>   \hline #> 1 & 5.10 & 3.50 & 1.40 & 0.20 & setosa \\  #>   2 & 4.90 & 3.00 & 1.40 & 0.20 & setosa \\  #>    \cline{3-4} #> 3 & 4.70 & 3.20 & 1.30 & 0.20 & setosa \\  #>    \cline{3-4} #> 4 & 4.60 & 3.10 & 1.50 & 0.20 & setosa \\  #>   5 & 5.00 & 3.60 & 1.40 & 0.20 & setosa \\  #>   6 & 5.40 & 3.90 & 1.70 & 0.40 & setosa \\  #>    \hline #> \end{tabular} #> \end{table}

what: For use with latex summary tables — add_multirow
title: For use with latex summary tables — add_multirow
text: Turns duplicate rows occur together NAs adds multirow remaining rows.

title: For use with latex summary tables — add_multirow
code: add_multirow(   x,   width = "*",   pos = "t",   rows = .,   reverse = FALSE,   hline = TRUE )

title: For use with latex summary tables — add_multirow
text: x Character vector width Desired width column passed multirow latex. e.g. "4cm" pos Character defining vertical positioning text multirow block. Default "t" - top. options "c" centre "b" bottom. rows Optional number rows use, given add_multirow calculates many rows use. reverse TRUE last duplicate removed. rows given calculated number rows negated. features useful colouring tables. hline Logical indicating whether hline added start multirow.

title: For use with latex summary tables — add_multirow
text: character string/vector

title: For use with latex summary tables — add_multirow
code:
x <- c(rep("a", 5), rep("c", 2), rep("y", 7))     add_multirow(x) #>  [1] "\hline
\multirow[t]{5}{*}{a}" NA                                #>  [3] NA                                NA                                #>  [5] NA                                "\hline
\multirow[t]{2}{*}{c}" #>  [7] NA                                "\hline
\multirow[t]{7}{*}{y}" #>  [9] NA                                NA                                #> [11] NA                                NA                                #> [13] NA                                NA                                    add_multirow(x, reverse = TRUE) #>  [1] NA                                 NA                                 #>  [3] NA                                 NA                                 #>  [5] "\hline
\multirow[t]{-5}{*}{a}" NA                                 #>  [7] "\hline
\multirow[t]{-2}{*}{c}" NA                                 #>  [9] NA                                 NA                                 #> [11] NA                                 NA                                 #> [13] NA                                 "\hline
\multirow[t]{-7}{*}{y}"     add_multirow(x, width = "2cm", pos = "c") #>  [1] "\hline
\multirow[c]{5}{2cm}{a}" NA                                  #>  [3] NA                                  NA                                  #>  [5] NA                                  "\hline
\multirow[c]{2}{2cm}{c}" #>  [7] NA                                  "\hline
\multirow[c]{7}{2cm}{y}" #>  [9] NA                                  NA                                  #> [11] NA                                  NA                                  #> [13] NA                                  NA

Move the column names of a data frame to a row — colnames_to_row
text: df data frame row row number column names inserted, default (.e., names become first row data frame).

title: Move the column names of a data frame to a row — colnames_to_row

what: Condense two or three columns into one — condense
title: Condense two or three columns into one — condense
text: Useful saving space summary tables created continuous_table(), discrete_table(), ticked_table() ae_table().

title: Condense two or three columns into one — condense
code: condense(   df,   first_col = variable,   second_col = scoring,   third_col,   hline = TRUE,   indent = c("quad", "hang", "space") )

title: Condense two or three columns into one — condense
text: df data frame containing least one column repeated values. first_col variable name column collapse - contain repeated values. Default variable quick use summary table functions. second_col variable name column collapsed first_col. Default scoring quick use summary table functions. third_col Optionally, third column collapsed second_col. hline Logical indicating whether "\\hline\n" added start unique value first_col. use xtable::xtable(). Default TRUE. indent Character indicating type indent use (default "quad"): "quad" uses \(\LaTeX\)'s \\quad indent second column (\\qquad \\quad indent third column given) "hang" uses \(\LaTeX\)'s \\hangindent2em\\hangafter0 indent second column (\\hangindent4em\\hangafter0 indent third column given) "space" uses "    " indent second column ("        " indent third column given)

title: Condense two or three columns into one — condense

what: Produce a data frame to summaries continuous variables — continuous_table
title: Produce a data frame to summaries continuous variables — continuous_table
text: Takes data frame produces grouped un-grouped summaries mean standard deviation continuous variables.

title: Produce a data frame to summaries continuous variables — continuous_table
code: continuous_table(   df = .,   ...,   group,   time,   total = TRUE,   digits = 2,   condense = FALSE )

title: Produce a data frame to summaries continuous variables — continuous_table
text: df Data frame ... Variables summarised group Optional variable defines grouping time Optional variable repeated measures (currently must used group) total Logical indicating whether total column created digits Number digits right decimal point condense condense = TRUE deprecated, use condense() instead.

title: Produce a data frame to summaries continuous variables — continuous_table
text: tibble data frame summarising data

title: Produce a data frame to summaries continuous variables — continuous_table
code: continuous_table(outcome, score, group = group) #> # A tibble: 5 × 5 #>   variable scoring      A                 B                 Total             #>   <chr>    <chr>        <chr>             <chr>             <chr>             #> 1 NA       NA           N = 276           N = 324           N = 600           #> 2 score    n            247               280               527               #> 3 score    Mean (SD)    4.12 (2.23)       6.46 (3.04)       5.36 (2.93)       #> 4 score    Median (IQR) 4.27 (2.59, 5.54) 6.20 (4.45, 8.74) 5.11 (3.24, 7.22) #> 5 score    Min, Max     -2.24, 9.89       -1.01, 14.58      -2.24, 14.58          continuous_table(outcome, score, group = group, condense = FALSE,                      total = FALSE) #> # A tibble: 5 × 4 #>   variable scoring      A                 B                 #>   <chr>    <chr>        <chr>             <chr>             #> 1 NA       NA           N = 276           N = 324           #> 2 score    n            247               280               #> 3 score    Mean (SD)    4.12 (2.23)       6.46 (3.04)       #> 4 score    Median (IQR) 4.27 (2.59, 5.54) 6.20 (4.45, 8.74) #> 5 score    Min, Max     -2.24, 9.89       -1.01, 14.58          continuous_table(outcome, score, digits = 1) #> # A tibble: 5 × 3 #>   variable scoring      value          #>   <chr>    <chr>        <chr>          #> 1 NA       NA           N = 600        #> 2 score    n            527            #> 3 score    Mean (SD)    5.4 (2.9)      #> 4 score    Median (IQR) 5.1 (3.2, 7.2) #> 5 score    Min, Max     -2.2, 14.6

what: Produce a data frame to summarise counts of events — count_table
title: Produce a data frame to summarise counts of events — count_table
text: Takes data frame events produces number events number percentage individuals least one event.

title: Produce a data frame to summarise counts of events — count_table
code: count_table(df, ..., ID, N, group, accuracy = 0.1, total = FALSE, all = FALSE)

title: Produce a data frame to summarise counts of events — count_table
text: df Data Frame ... Variables summarised ID Variable defines individual identifier (e.g. screening number) N data frame group counts (typically produced using dplyr::count()) group optional, variable defines grouping accuracy see details scales::percent() total Logical indicating whether total column created, default FALSE logical indicating whether row summarising events created, default FALSE

title: Produce a data frame to summarise counts of events — count_table
code: N <- dplyr::count(outcome, group, name = "N")   count_table(outcome_aes, serious, related, ID = screening, N = N,               group = group) #> # A tibble: 5 × 6 #>   variable scoring A_events A_individuals B_events B_individuals #>   <chr>    <chr>   <chr>    <chr>         <chr>    <chr>         #> 1 NA       NA      N = 276  N = 276       N = 324  N = 324       #> 2 serious  No      45       37 (13.4%)    45       36 (11.1%)    #> 3 serious  Yes     4        4 (1.4%)      6        6 (1.9%)      #> 4 related  No      47       39 (14.1%)    50       41 (12.7%)    #> 5 related  Yes     2        2 (0.7%)      1        1 (0.3%)         N <- dplyr::count(outcome, name = "N")   count_table(outcome_aes, serious, related, ID = screening, N = N) #> # A tibble: 5 × 4 #>   variable scoring events  individuals #>   <chr>    <chr>   <chr>   <chr>       #> 1 NA       NA      N = 600 N = 600     #> 2 serious  No      90      73 (12.2%)  #> 3 serious  Yes     10      10 (1.7%)   #> 4 related  No      97      80 (13.3%)  #> 5 related  Yes     3       3 (0.5%)      count_table(outcome_aes, serious, ID = screening, N = N, all = TRUE) #> # A tibble: 4 × 4 #>   variable scoring events  individuals #>   <chr>    <chr>   <chr>   <chr>       #> 1 NA       NA      N = 600 N = 600     #> 2 All      n       100     82 (13.7%)  #> 3 serious  No      90      73 (12.2%)  #> 4 serious  Yes     10      10 (1.7%)

what: Produce a data frame to summarise discrete variables — discrete_table
title: Produce a data frame to summarise discrete variables — discrete_table
text: Takes data frame produces number percentage discrete variables.

title: Produce a data frame to summarise discrete variables — discrete_table
code: discrete_table(   df = .,   ...,   group,   time,   total = TRUE,   n = FALSE,   missing = "Missing",   accuracy = 0.1,   drop.levels = FALSE,   condense = FALSE )

title: Produce a data frame to summarise discrete variables — discrete_table
text: df Data Frame ... Variables summarised group Optional variable defines grouping time Optional variable repeated measures (currently must used group) total Logical indicating whether total column created n Logical indicating whether percentages n (n = TRUE) N (n = FALSE) missing String determining missing data called (n = TRUE). Default "Missing". accuracy see details scales::label_percent() drop.levels logical indicating whether unused levels factors dropped. Default FALSE. condense condense = TRUE deprecated, use condense() instead.

title: Produce a data frame to summarise discrete variables — discrete_table
text: tibble data frame summarising data

title: Produce a data frame to summarise discrete variables — discrete_table
code: discrete_table(outcome, sex, group = group) #> # A tibble: 5 × 5 #>   variable scoring               A           B           Total       #>   <chr>    <chr>                 <chr>       <chr>       <chr>       #> 1 NA       NA                    N = 276     N = 324     N = 600     #> 2 sex      Female                144 (52.2%) 159 (49.1%) 303 (50.5%) #> 3 sex      Male                  129 (46.7%) 162 (50.0%) 291 (48.5%) #> 4 sex      Prefer not to specify 0 (0.0%)    0 (0.0%)    0 (0.0%)    #> 5 sex      Missing               3 (1.1%)    3 (0.9%)    6 (1.0%)        discrete_table(outcome, sex, drop.levels = TRUE) #> # A tibble: 4 × 3 #>   variable scoring value       #>   <chr>    <chr>   <chr>       #> 1 NA       NA      N = 600     #> 2 sex      Female  303 (50.5%) #> 3 sex      Male    291 (48.5%) #> 4 sex      Missing 6 (1.0%)        discrete_table(outcome, sex, group = group, time = event_name, n = TRUE,                    total = FALSE) #> # A tibble: 13 × 5 #>    event_name variable scoring               A          B          #>    <chr>      <chr>    <chr>                 <chr>      <chr>      #>  1 NA         NA       NA                    N = 92     N = 108    #>  2 Baseline   sex      n                     91         107        #>  3 Baseline   sex      Female                48 (52.7%) 53 (49.5%) #>  4 Baseline   sex      Male                  43 (47.3%) 54 (50.5%) #>  5 Baseline   sex      Prefer not to specify 0 (0.0%)   0 (0.0%)   #>  6 6 Weeks    sex      n                     91         107        #>  7 6 Weeks    sex      Female                48 (52.7%) 53 (49.5%) #>  8 6 Weeks    sex      Male                  43 (47.3%) 54 (50.5%) #>  9 6 Weeks    sex      Prefer not to specify 0 (0.0%)   0 (0.0%)   #> 10 12 Weeks   sex      n                     91         107        #> 11 12 Weeks   sex      Female                48 (52.7%) 53 (49.5%) #> 12 12 Weeks   sex      Male                  43 (47.3%) 54 (50.5%) #> 13 12 Weeks   sex      Prefer not to specify 0 (0.0%)   0 (0.0%)

Determines whether ignore case exact = FALSE.

title: Searches a list of dataframes. — search_list
text: data.frame

title: Searches a list of dataframes. — search_list
code: files <- list(mtcars = mtcars, iris = iris) search_list(files, "Sepal", exact = FALSE) #>   file     variable #> 1 iris Sepal.Length #> 2 iris  Sepal.Width search_list(files, "hp") #>     file variable #> 1 mtcars       hp

what: Tools for working with column names — split_colnames
title: Tools for working with column names — split_colnames
text: Splits column names two rows. first row new column names, second first row data.

title: Tools for working with column names — split_colnames
Tools for working with column names — split_colnames
text: df data frame. sep Separator column names first row.

what: Sets up the analysis folder — start_analysis
title: Sets up the analysis folder — start_analysis
text: start_analysis() creates new directory creates recommended folder structure, copies template Master.R Read-data.R scripts, optionally creates .gitignore file template statistics report also included Useful.functions.

title: Sets up the analysis folder — start_analysis
code: start_analysis(   path,   createGitignore = TRUE,   rprofile = TRUE,   statsReport = NULL )

title: Sets up the analysis folder — start_analysis
text: path path new analysis folder createGitignore logical indicating whether .gitignore file created standard items git ignore. Default TRUE. rprofile logical indicating whether project .Rprofile created automatically open Master.R script project opened. Default TRUE. statsReport optional character string name statistics report created. created Reports folder.

title: Sets up the analysis folder — start_analysis
text: template package can also implemented RStudio IDE.

what: Function to recreate the expand function in Stata — stata_expand
title: Function to recreate the expand function in Stata — stata_expand
text: Takes dataframe duplicates n times, creates variable (default name Duplicate) value 0 observation originally appeared int dataset = 1,..,n duplicate.

title: Function to recreate the expand function in Stata — stata_expand
Function to recreate the expand function in Stata — stata_expand
text: df Data frame n Number times duplicate (.e. end 2 copies everything n = 1) name Character string indicating name variable indicating rows duplicates

text: data frame

text: x factor vector width Positive integer giving target line width (number characters). width less equal 1 put word line. ... arguments passed stringr::str_wrap

title: String wrapping for factor variables — strwrap_factor
text: factor vector length x factor levels wrapped

title: String wrapping for factor variables — strwrap_factor
code:
nt_yorks <- factor(c("Beningbrough Hall (Historic House)",                      "Braithwaite Hall (Historic Property)",                      "Brimham Rocks (Countryside)",                      "East Riddlesden Hall (Historic House)",                      "Fountains Abbey (Abbey)",                      "Gibson's Mill (Historic Property)",                      "Goddards House & Garden (Historic House)",                      "Hardcastle Crags (Countryside)",                      "Hudswell Woods (Countryside)",                      "Maister House (Historic Property)",                      "Moulton Hall (Historic Property)",                      "Nostell Priory (Historic House)",                      "Nunnington Hall (Historic Property)",                      "Rievaulx Terrace and Temples (Garden)",                      "Roseberry Topping (Countryside)",                      "Studley Royal Water Garden (Garden)",                      "The Bridestones (Countryside)",                      "Treasurers House (Historic Property)"))  strwrap_factor(nt_yorks, width = 10) #>  [1] Beningbrough

what: Produce a dataframe to summarise ticked variables — ticked_table
title: Produce a dataframe to summarise ticked variables — ticked_table
text: Takes dataframe produces number percentage ticked variables.

title: Produce a dataframe to summarise ticked variables — ticked_table
code: ticked_table(   df = .,   ...,   group,   sep,   digits = 1,   total = TRUE,   condense = FALSE )

title: Produce a dataframe to summarise ticked variables — ticked_table
text: df Data Frame ... Variables summarised group Optional variable defines grouping sep Optional separator columns splitting variable variable scoring. See ?tidyr::separate information. digits Number digits right decimal point total Logical indicating whether total column created condense condense = TRUE deprecated, use condense() instead.

title: Produce a dataframe to summarise ticked variables — ticked_table
text: tibble data frame summarising data

title: Produce a dataframe to summarise ticked variables — ticked_table
code: ticked_table(outcome, pet_cat, pet_dog, group = group, sep = "_") #> # A tibble: 3 × 5 #>   variable scoring A          B           Total       #>   <chr>    <chr>   <chr>      <chr>       <chr>       #> 1 NA       NA      N = 276    N = 324     N = 600     #> 2 pet      cat     48 (17.4%) 75 (23.1%)  123 (20.5%) #> 3 pet      dog     96 (34.8%) 105 (32.4%) 201 (33.5%)    ticked_table(outcome, pet_fish, pet_dog) #> # A tibble: 3 × 2 #>   scoring  value       #>   <chr>    <chr>       #> 1 NA       N = 600     #> 2 pet_fish 99 (16.5%)  #> 3 pet_dog  201 (33.5%)

what: Wrangle the Edith database specification into a single lookups data frame — wrangle_lookups
title: Wrangle the Edith database specification into a single lookups data frame — wrangle_lookups
text: function takes Lookups Fields tabs Edith database specification (exported separate csv files) wrangles single lookups data frame use read_prospect() apply_labels().

title: Wrangle the Edith database specification into a single lookups data frame — wrangle_lookups
code: wrangle_lookups(lookups, fields, clean = FALSE, keep = NULL)

title: Wrangle the Edith database specification into a single lookups data frame — wrangle_lookups
text: lookups data frame read Lookups.csv file exported Edith fields data frame read Fields.csv file exported Edith clean logical indicating whether field field_label columns cleaned : removing "[calculated] " field column removing "[Calculated] " "Calculated " field_label column converting field_label column sentence case keep optional character vector specifying additional fields keep fields

title: Useful.functions (development version)
text: ae_table() renamed count_table() new function condense() condense 2/3 columns 1 deprecated use condense = TRUE continuous_table(), discrete_table() ticked_table() update git_log() multiple git tags kept one column update ticked_table() include digits option new project template function initiate start_analysis() added new option drop.levels drop unused levels. update statistics-report R Markdown template allow landscape report new R Markdown template presentations updates documentation throughout clarity

title: Useful.functions 0.3.0
text: Initial NEWS, future changes summarised
